recordings.rmk:
This bird resembles a common blackbird, however it only sings as uploaded. I never heard it singing the usual blackbird song, and all the recordings of the blackbird alarm calls sound different to me.

Is it actually the alarm call of a common blackbird, or it is a different species/subspecies?

The first and the last sound typical Blackbird song to my eras but what about those deeper and clearer sounds at 3-4 s and that short one at 7 s? The lower and clearer voice made me think about Oriole but the melody from my limited experience doesnt fit so well with that species?

recordings.loc: Royal Victoria Park, Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Mimicry of various emergency vehicle sirens. There are three sounds that are imitated: the "wail" e.g. at 0:41, the "yelp" e.g. at 0:31 and "piercer" e.g. at 0:26. These are the standard Whelan sirens used by the police and by ambulances travelling to the Royal United Hospital in Bath which is just a few hundred metres up the road.

It is interesting to see how the Blackbird incorporates the sounds into its song. In this case the basis of the song is dominated by siren sounds with fewer verses sounding like a typical Blackbird verse. Even those verses with normal structure appear to have been influenced by the sirens and have lots of repeated notes and occassional snippets of "yelp" and parts of the "wail" (e.g. the opening verse and 0:17). 

An actual "wail" siren is a continuous sound which rises and falls in pitch. When the Blackbird tries to copy this sound it seemingly cannot replicate the continuous nature of it; the final result is 10 or so shorter notes strung together to give the impression of a siren. This is best seen by looking at the sonogram. 

In addition to the sirens, this bird also appears to mimic a Magpie at 6:33.7 and the sound of a metallic object being struck at 3:43. 

Noted as male based on plumage.  

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 microphone handheld. Very lightly edited below 300 Hz to reduce some background rumble and handling noise.

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).

Very nice call of a male doing a series of territorial displays including moving very fast the wings raise the head feathers and make constant attacks against a Cyanistes coeruleus. Also He flew to another tree and was also delivering this call. I consider that the call was territorial.
Singing from rooftop antenna in town.

Recital de mirlo grabado antes de amanecer. el ejemplar es uno de los machos residentes que ha elegido como atalaya de canto una gran encina que hay en la zona ajardinada del palacio de Viana. durante unos días sus llamadas nocturnas eran más insistentes, seguramente por tener a su hembra incubando una segunda puesta y disponer de más tiempo para marcar el territorio. Como sabía que en cuanto nacieran los polluelos cantaría bastante menos aproveché esos días para grabarlo en el silencio de la noche. Además de vez en cuándo se escuchan los chillidos de algún murciélago que pasa y el llamado de otro macho de mirlo que responde en la lejanía.
  Es sabido que los mirlos urbanos modifican sus horas de canto para evitar los momentos de mayor ruido de tráfico, por eso éste canta a horas tan intempestivas.

  Grabación realizada a 160 kbps.

recordings.loc: Rda. Sant Ramon - Miquel (near  Sant Boi de Llobregat), Barcelona, Catalunya
recordings.rmk: Grabación obtenida mediante la técnica de NocMig, con una grabadora Olympus LS-P4.  Zona ajardinada de población mediana. De fondo se puede escuchar cantar al Herrerillo.

The subsong, or high pitch interval, was provoked by a Turdus merula female, being attracted to his song. The female merula placed herself on the ground, under the tree the male was singing, and when she left,  the male was again turning on  to his usual singing.

recordings.loc: Ireland (near  Bangor), Ards And North Down, Northern Ireland
recordings.rmk: Blackbirds are renowned for being alarmists. This clip contains a selection of their edgy calls. Lower-pitched 'chook' calls feature at 0:01 (three repeats of the same note), 0:03 (two repeats) and 0:06 (three repeats). Two less loud 'chook' bursts follow. Higher-pitched 'chink' notes are at 0:09 (five repeats). Alarm rattles are at 0:11, 0:15, 0:20 and 0:25. After this, less loud 'chink' calls feature, giving way to a final 'chook' series (three repeats) at 0:27. Note how the three types of agitated calls - from lower chook to higher chink to 'wall of sound' alarm - are interchangeable and are at the whim of the bird. All calls were made by the same bird.

recordings.type: alarm call, life stage uncertain, sex uncertain
recordings.rmk: Alarm burst from a Blackbird among a soundtrack recorded remotely.

recordings.loc: Ireland (near  Bangor), Ards And North Down, Northern Ireland
recordings.rmk: A clip of Blackbird's assertive 'chinking' that is a common accompaniment to a lot of the bird's 'nosy parker' lifestyle and is especially used prior to roost. Two bursts of chinking are followed by the contact call from a juvenile (the high and rising whistle) and, finally, song from a nearby male. The recording was made in a garden where several Blackbirds commonly hung out.

Singing from tall poplar trees.  Not seen. Also Common Woodpigeon and Hobby (latter faintly from 1:26).

Recorded on a fine morning at the RSPB nature reserve, Exminster Marshes, with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 on a tripod. Although I did not see the bird whilst it was giving the call, it gave an further Blackbird call (not recorded) and was seen flying out of the hawthorn a few seconds after the end of the sequence of calls so I am satisfied that the recording is of that Blackbird. The recording also includes adult and juvenile calls of Reed Warblers in the background.  Eq edited below 1800 Hz to reduce road noise.

recordings.loc: Royal Victoria Park, Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Recorded on a clear morning in an urban park. EQ adjusted below 2000 Hz using Audacity to reduce road noise. I think the bird stopped singing just one verse after I stopped recording. 

There is plenty of mimicry here, but I find it's only noticeable if you start playing back the track in certain places. Most of the mimicking seems to take place in the quieter endings to each verse. Have a listen to the links below. If you can hear any more, or think I've made any mistakes then please press "discuss" to leave a comment.

Imitations:

Swift (0:29.25 2:19.1 and 6:18.9),

Swallow (0:30.0 2:19.9 4:48.3 6:19.65 6:40.5 and 8:17.6),

Green Woodpecker (0:46.6 2:08.2 3:19.0 5:34.5 and 6:45.3),

Green Woodpecker (3:37.3 and 7:28.0),

Tawny Owl call (0:52.5 4:47.1 6:13.8 6:39.3 and 8:16.3),

Tawny Owl begging call (6:52.4),

Magpie (?) (1:03.8 and 3:56.8),

Magpie (?) (2:31.8 and 7:01.7),

Magpie (?) (3:24.2 5:13.4 and 6:21.0),

Coal Tit (3:08.0 5:29.9 and 7:15.4),

Coal Tit (3:24.5 and 6:21.3),

Robin (0:47.0 3:19.35 and 6:45.7),

House alarm (?) (3:42.55 5:40.0 and 7:20.7),

Squeeky toy (?) (4:26.7 and 7:32.2).


Reference recording for Swallow: XC343873

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).

One male doing a beautiful and complex song delivered from a exposed perch in a tree for almost 8 minutes. Almost sure this sound is related with mating and territorial advertisement. Recording distance was 5 meters , beautiful and sunny spring day.
